REVIEW_TITLE: Surreal Moments in A Busy City
REVIEW_BODY: Rising from the ground like out of Gotham City, the building is built with an Art Deco old New York style era. Interesting gargoyles decorate the outer facade of the building, while the surrounding grounds below resembles Venice's San Marco's Square. One could easily forget that they are in the midst of a busy city when strolling through the open grounds below. It is not a retail mall though, but an office building. Not a usual tourist spot, but you could pass by it if you are walking towards DUO or Haji Lane. Worth taking a look if only to marvel at the building and the many interesting sculptures and statues dotting the ground. Nice place for architectural photography
The place is beautiful. So many amazing sculptures. Not far from bugis junction. Nice place to take photos.
You can easily miss this building crossing by , Its interesting & impressive art deco building .Do visit

The most striking part of the building is the ceiling in the lobby. Truth be told, I have only been in the lobby and outdoors. With uncanny skill, our 2 trips to Singapore have been while the museum has been closed. Still, Botero, Dali and several other sculptors grace the exterior and the design of the building is itself marvelous. The museum has changing exhibits of different sorts (sharks closed and an art theme would open soon) and - it's free. In addition to the bar and offices, the building has embassies for Austria, Mongolia and the United Arab Emirates.
This amazing restaurant, coffee shop and a bar totally reminded of Harry Porter! Fantastic interior and great tea time. Very artistic and unique place perfect for picture taking.

This is a building that you can‚Äôt help but notice. It‚Äôs imposing brown granite facade with its cathedral-like portico.

While a relatively new building (2002) it is like something taken straight out of Manhattan, a replica Art Deco masterpiece.

The open plaza features a number od sculptures.

REVIEW_TITLE: A great place for a G&T
REVIEW_BODY: We came across this by accident. Having seen the building from the outside, we decided to investigate and were very glad we do. Whilst it is a new building, it looks and feels very old. Externally that are a lot of modern schedules but internally it feels like you are back in the 1930s. We just sat and had a G&T and there are hundreds to chose from, each grouped by country. The place was very busy with many people enjoying afternoon tea which looked amazing. We tried to visit agin on Sunday but it was closed, so beware. You may not find this in many guides but definitely worth making the effort go

We visited at midday, as suggested to view the ‚Äú Intriguing Uncertainties‚Äù Exhibition.
The exhibition space is on the third level by lift. Some very large paintings on view with a number of line, pencil and charcoal works by a number of world contemporary artists.
Entry is free and found it an interesting way to fill some time on our last day in Singapore. There is also a large and likely very expensive restaurant on the 2nd floor entrance point.
Can‚Äôt believe this building was built not that long ago. Beautiful lines, gardens and mind blowing statues. I wish it was open when I was going past

We were told about this building and bar by friends who had recently returned from Singapore and they encouraged us to check it out. So glad we did! The building is impressive and yes it does look like something out of Gotham City. The interior is amazing. We were directed to a cosy table and ordered our very expensive drinks and were told that we only had until 5pm because a strict dress code was enforced after that...fair enough as we were in very casual sight seeing attire!!! Thoroughly enjoyed our drink which we sipped and we made them last for nearly an hour!! Glad we came as it was something very different for Singapore.

We happened to walk past this building on the way to the subway on our first day in Singapore. We were impressed from the outside so wandered in to take a look.
It is a wonderful building with so much at deco detail to admire.
Imagine our surprise therefore when we found out that it was built between 1999 and 2003. Wonderful attention to detail

Walked passed this building so many times. Finally I made an effort to pay a visit. I was impressed by the various art work display around the building compound. Felt like I have entered into a museum. They even have a nice European deco caf√© inside the building.

REVIEW_TITLE: Fairy didn't fly on the night, though stairs were used, Gothamesque building it is in, would be very hard to miss
REVIEW_BODY:
Interesting for a brief period, and some good people watching.
Just be aware, from early evening a[n inconsistent] dress code applies, and the service took a while to get going.
Apparently the place is under new management, outside numerous statues of poets and philosophers were replaced by a glowing shark fin, and so on.

We didn't know about this place. We just noticed this very imposing building on the landscape so eventually walked to it. What a discovery! Every part of this building and its surrounds is a work of art.It took our breath away. Inside and outside.The fact that it is only 15 years old, and not from New York in the 1920's is staggering.I'm not going into detail. You just need to go and discover it for yourself.

REVIEW_TITLE: Closed on Sunday, but impressive nonetheless
REVIEW_BODY: This is an astounding building that is not the tourist hotspot you'd think it should be. Incredible art deco style building and decorations, and the ground floor bar is breathtaking. It was closed the Sunday I went, but I'm assured it's worth a visit. Just to stand there and take in the atmosphere is incredible. Lots of photo ops

REVIEW_TITLE: If this is Gotham City, Where‚Äôs Batman???
REVIEW_BODY:
This is a very impressive Art Deco looking building both inside and out that we went to as part of a walking tour. Unfortunately they were doing some renovations inside at the time so you could get the full impact of the architecture.

Apparently it is also affectionately referred to as ‚ÄùGotham City‚Äù, so if you can‚Äôt find it just send out the Bat Signal.

Worth a look if you are in the Bugis and Kampong Glam areas.
Parview Square aka Gotham City of Singapore is located near the City Hall MRT station. Amazing architecture! It's just wow! üôÄ

What a wonderful find! We went on a fabulous walking tour (Indie Singapore tours) and our fantastic guide Wei stopped to show us this Art Deco gem of a building. It's hard to believe that it was built in 2000! The lobby area is open to the public, but as the building houses three embassies, there is a security presence. The lobby area has the most fantastic bar with a 4 storey high wine cabinet. The only way to get the wine down is by way of a silver wine fairy (the waitress is dressed as a silver fairy and uses a pulley to get around the cabinet -one must see it to believe it!). Because it's off the beaten track this is a nice quieter place to have a drink, surrounded by beautiful decor!

REVIEW_TITLE: Where are all the architecture buffs?
REVIEW_BODY: As already noted, this was not to be found in all my reading about Singapore, even though I was really interested in the fabulous and varied architecture. We got off the subway to go to Little India and saw this amazing building about a block away. It was a Saturday, and the area was totally deserted. If you have money and want to spend it ostentatiously and you love Art Deco, this is what you do. What an indulgence! From the exterior gates to the amazing forecourt, which I later read was fashioned after the Piazza San Marco in Venice, with bronze statues of famous historical figures and a golden crane that faces mainland China, the owner's homeland. There is not a nook or cranny that isn't decorated with precision style. Gargoyles, fountains, you name it. The office building appeared off-limits, but the guard let us in for a few moments to look at the lobby. Again, all you can do is gape in amazement at what went into this creation. We were too early to see the "wine fairy" (check out YouTube...) retrieve wine from the two story wine rack, but we could still admire the extraordinary effort put into decorating this building. In my later reading, it said that it is one of the most expensive office buildings in Singapore (and that's saying something), with several consulates, and office space with no pillars so tenants can design the space as they like. It was only just built in 2002, but what a tribute to the Art Deco style. If you are wandering around Singapore, take a look. It is well worth the short walk from the Metro.

Stumbled across this building on my way to Kampong Glam. I was completely drawn in. One of the most incredible buildings I have seen. It‚Äôs an office building which houses 5 embassies (well, that‚Äôs what I was told). Allow time to check this out. You won‚Äôt be disappointed.

Walking along Victoria St this imposing building stood out amongst its neighbors and drew me on a detour to visit. It was built only in 2002 but heavily influenced inside and out by the Art Deco period.

Inside the main courtyard were a number of unusual statues that ranged from massive in size to whimsical. Palm trees provided welcoming shade from the hot sun while lots of greenery and a waterfall made this a nice spot to relax.

Walking into the building, I came face to face with the over the top Divine Wine Bar with its gilded ceiling and walls, huge murals and the wine storage that rose all the way to the ceiling. I was told that the staff have to use special contraption just to reach these bottles. That would be a site to see on a future visit.
I was staying at a nearby hotel and took a stroll over to the square. What a pretty oasis - beautiful sculptures and a water feature. Great place to take photos and take a pause from a busy day.

REVIEW_TITLE: An impressive building and pleasant square well worth exploring a little.
REVIEW_BODY:
I came across Parkview Square by pure chance as I took an afternoon walk down North Bridge Road. The stunning architecture caught my eye so I went and explored my chance find... The fun of world travel. This is one of the most expensive office buildings in Singapore and home to the Embassy of the UAE among others. It is also home to the amazing Atlas Bar and the Parkview Museum (See my other reviews). Despite its appearance it is actually a modern building completed in 2002 and designed by the US firm James Adams Design, it has just been done in a stunning and very authentic classic Art Deco style... Go inside and check it out it's amazing!!
The 'Square' is very pleasant with arty statues, greenery and places to rest a while and relax. When I walked back at night it was beautiful all illuminated. Certainly well worth a visit.
Back again to Parkview Square Its still good towers with offices and cafes beside it some new towers added to the tower some arst of designs

Came here as i read about parkview museum. If not for the museum, i doubt there's a reason for me to come

Not sure if i would call it art deco, but it may have aspired to be. The decor is over the top for an office building

REVIEW_TITLE: Art deco architecture, with amazing art gallery space
REVIEW_BODY: This building has captured my attention every single time I walk past it when I'm in the vicinity. The architecture is amazing and stands out in the bugis district because of how grandiose it looks. I chanced upon an opportunity to go inside the building when a certain level was converted to an art gallery space and was amazed by the collection they possess. On the first floor is an amazing gin bar worth checking out. Don't miss out on this place if you are visiting the bugis and Arab quarter

This is a beautiful building to stumble by on my way to Arab Street in Singapore. It is pristine! Be sure to walk into the courtyard and then into the lobby! Beautiful statues are through out! It is a treasure hidden amongst older lesser maintained buildings ! Wonderful
the building is doing upgrades...so some status are removed , the restaurent is also under going renovation.

My best discovery in Singapore for sure was completely blown away by what the locals call the batman building. The most expensive office building in Singapore this place will totally blow you away from the amazing bronze statues outside (Churchill, Plato, Socrates, Shakespeare, Picasso, Raffles himself and many many more) this building is just incredible. Then you go inside and my jaw hit the floor as you're thrown into the Gatsby-esque grandeur it's just stunning. Alas no wine fairy as it was morning but the bars at each end of the room are stunning with its high wine racks baby grand piano and the sumptuous decor. Visiting as early as I did also meant I had the place to myself which actually was kinda nice!

REVIEW_TITLE: Don't miss bar/cafe at the first floor!! So fabulous!
REVIEW_BODY:
I visited the building for a meeting with customer. The customer invited me to a cafe/bar "Atlas Bar" at the first floor (or Ground floor?). It was so fabulous and gorgeous. In Japan, we can not see cafe like the one. Though prices in drinks at the bar are little expensive compared with others, the bar is worth visiting. The atmosphere made me feel relax and that I am so sophisticated person. I heard a rumor that long time ago at the bar, girls with very attractive wearing took wine bottle from wine shelf when customer order a bottle of wine. But I am not sure it is true or not.

REVIEW_TITLE: Interesting art deco building, worth a visit if nearby
REVIEW_BODY:
This is a fairly new building and square, near Raffles hotel. It is quite unique as it is art deco in design including bronze and glass. It is referred to by locals as the "Gotham Building." Mostly because it looks like something out of a Gotham/Batman movie.

I enjoyed the exterior and the cool bar inside. Lots of photo ops and not very many tourists. Worth a visit while nearby, quite unique.

REVIEW_TITLE: 1930s Art Deco stylish building and grounds
REVIEW_BODY: Has a great garden surrounding it. Looks like a building from Gotham City Parking underneath and offices upstairs. The ground floor bar is large and excellent

REVIEW_TITLE: Generic office block but very cool Art Deco exterior and interior
REVIEW_BODY: This place is quite incongruous - it's just an office block but the ground floor is fairly OTT Art Deco, massive statues and all. There's a cafe in the middle but I wouldn't say it's worth a visit unless you are an architecture buff, in which case it's a must see.
This is one of the pretty building here.A place to spend a few minutes.You can see when you go past if you have time stop and have look.

The Parkview Square building is the iconic, imposing, art deco building and reportedly one of the most expensive office buildings in Singapore. It is often affectionately referred to as Gotham Square because it bears a striking resemblance to Gotham City.
In the lobby you will find the Divine Bar ATLAS, one of the best and elegant bars in Singapore. The decor is simply stunning and will export you to 19th century feels.
Stumbled across this building like going back to the 1920. Was looking for the museum but was closed. Just pop in you can get drinks at the restaurant on ground floor,unbelievable see pictures.

Parkview Square is architecturally fascinating and a haven for people who appreciate sculptures. The sculptures are an eclectic mix including some from Salvador Dali, which feature in other parts of Singapore.

Getting there: MRT to Bugis or from Orchard bus #7. It‚Äôs opposite the large Raffles Hospital and next to the honey comb looking buildings. It‚Äôs hot with most sculptures in full sun (depending on the time of day), so 10-20 minutes will do it.

Tie a visit in to Parkview Square with a Kampong Glam walk: Sultan Mosque, Haji Lane, Arab Street, and Zam Zam for murtabak.

Parkview Square is not tourist's hot spot. Yet thanks to my church brother from Singapore for bringing me there - a free place to show different aspects of Singapore.

I am impressed by the statues around the square. There are quite a number of interesting and funny statues there. The golden bird is beautiful and meaningful. The fat woman statue is amusing. Although I didn‚Äôt go inside the Altas bar in Parkview, I had already been fascinated by its antique atmosphere.

There is a small museum on the third floor of Parkview. It is more like a gallery yet it is worthwhile for visiting. The paintings and artworks there are creative. I especially like the Aldo Mondino painting which really can bring out the Turkish dancing motion and act like the music is on.

The Chinese calligraphy scrolls in the museum are pretty nice as well.

On a morning walk happened upon this square and building Artdeco in style loads of great sculptures around and the building is amazing. There is a gallery in the building which was closed for change of exhibition the day we were there. There is an amazingly cool bar on the ground floor called Atlas which is a must visit

The buildings here are very grand and fascinating. The interior design is like the 1930's art decor style. There are many interesting sculptures and statues around. It is a rather unique place to visit in Singapore, especially if there you are into architecture.

This architectural marvel one of the most outstanding and iconic building stands among the Singapore skyscrapers. Unique and post modern architecture added an extraordinary value to one busy commercial building in the downtown Singapore. Love this view each and every time.

Walked through this building today for the first time in a while and noticed that the statues seem to have changed. No more famous philosophers. The building continues to impress, and the lobby and lobby bar are as appealing as ever. Worth a look.

REVIEW_TITLE: Park View Square - beautiful Art Deco building
REVIEW_BODY:
We fell upon this by accident -what a treasure! We were unaware of the 'sharks and humanity' exhibition and after admiring the exterior statues and crane the mesh shark fin didn't give us any idea of what was in store for us on the upper floor.
The ground floor is truly a blast from the past, but being late morning we didn't see the wine fairy. The staff didn't mind us wandering around admiring and photographing the interior. A visit to the ladies cloakroom was a revelation - heated loo seats!!
The exhibition was in several rooms,each shark [probably 1/4 size?] was depicted in different materials: metals, acrylics and like a helium balloons looking as if swimming, either suspended on steel ropes or supported on a couple of poles.
Fortunate that this special exhibition coincided with our tine in Singapore. Park View Square is definitely somewhere I would visit again when next in Singapore,

Beautiful and unusual place to visit for a drink or two! You will definitely need your camera as you will be taking photos inside and out (day time). The wine fairy is great to see too! One American lady took photos in the ladies powder room!

I was being shown around Singapore for a day by a friend who said I should prepare myself for something over-the-top. And there it was, Parkview. My age-old gripe is that buildings these days (in the UK at least) are built to last 30 years. I disagreed with m friend - I didn't see it as over-the-top, but a fabulous building which makes a huge statement. You can read its history elsewhere, but I would say without hesitation that it's worth a short MRT or bus ride. The building is a recreation of one in New York, but there is fantastic design and detail both inside and out (although sadly the inside was being renovated when we visited, so I missed the flying fairy retrieving wine from the 30m rack. Maybe that would have been over-the-top!). Go and be glad that someone cared enough to make something beautiful.

REVIEW_TITLE: Gorgeous art deco architecture and insides
REVIEW_BODY: With Gotham-harkening architecture and insides the like of Bioshock, this building is a must-see, especially for anyone even semi-interested in video games or art deco. This place is just gorgeous. It's actually a hotel lobby, but it's so incredibly decorous besides that that it's definitely worth visiting.

We went here on a Saturday evening to have a drink because the friend I was visiting (expat in Singapore) wanted to show me the 'Batman Building' and see the 'Wine Angels'. I believe the locals call it the Batman Building because it looks like it belongs in Gotham City, it is a lovely building, with a very nice bar that takes up the majority of the lobby; with a piano player and singer on the mezzanine it felt more like a cool hotel lobby than that of an office building. You don't have to wait long for the Wine Angel to fly up the vertical cellar and retrieve a bottle of wine, I think people order a bottle of wine just for the theatrics.
I also had the best Singapore Sling at this bar.
